para.paratext: O.C.G.A. § 24-8-801(c) defines hearsay as a statement, other than one made by the declarant while testifying at the trial or hearing, offered in evidence to prove the truth of the matter asserted. A “statement” may be either an oral or written assertion or some type of nonverbal conduct of a person, if such conduct was intended to be an assertion.

The Evidence Code distinguishes between out-of-court statements that are deemed hearsay but fall within an applicable exception to hearsay and those that are not deemed hearsay at all. For instance, the following out of court statements are not hearsay: (1) those previously made by a testifying witness for the purpose of impeachment or rehabilitation; O.C.G.A. § 24-8-801(d)(1)(A);[1] and (2) those made by a nontestifying declarant (whose hearsay statement was admitted in evidence under an exception) for the purpose of impeachment or rehabilitation; O.C.G.A. § 24-8-801(d)(1)(B). Moreover, under O.C.G.A. § 24-8-801(d)(2)(E), statements by a coconspirator of a party made during the course and in furtherance of the conspiracy are also admissible against the party.[2]
Whether the out-of-court statement is hearsay depends on whether it is offered for its truth or for some other reason, such as merely for the fact that it was made.[3]

In Chrysler Group, LLC v. Walden,[4] the Court of Appeals held that an NHTSA recall letter confirming the existence of certain safety defects in a vehicle was not offered to prove the existence of the safety defects but rather, at least in part, to support an inference that a subsequent meeting between the CEO of Chrysler and the NHTSA led to a change in NHTSA's opinion that the vehicle did not pose an unreasonable safety risk. As a result, the court found that the letter was not hearsay and therefore admissible.

In Jones v. State,[5] the Court of Appeals found that a recorded telephone call between a nontestifying informant and defendant in which the defendant made incriminating statements did not constitute hearsay because it was offered to provide context for the defendant's portion of the conversation, not for the truth of the matter asserted. Most of the hearsay exceptions cover statements that are not testimonial. Business records,[6] dying declarations,[7] and coconspirator statements[8] are excepted from the rule.

An out-of-court statement shall not be hearsay if the declarant testifies at the trial or hearing, is subject to cross examination concerning the statement, and the statement is admissible as a prior inconsistent statement or a prior consistent statement under Code Section 24-6-613 or is otherwise admissible under this chapter.
Brown v. State, 332 Ga. App. 635, 774 S.E.2d 708 (2015).
Chrysler Group, LLC v. Walden, 339 Ga. App. 733, 792 S.E.2d 754 (2016).
Jones v. State, 339 Ga. App. 95, 791 S.E.2d 625 (2016).

O.C.G.A. § 24-8-803(6); Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. 36, 124 S. Ct. 1354, 158 L. Ed. 2d 177, 63 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 1077 (2004). See, e.g., Rackoff v. State, 275 Ga. App. 737, 621 S.E.2d 841 (2005) (routine record of inspection of breathalyzer was nontestimonial).
See Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. 36, 56, 124 S. Ct. 1354, 158 L. Ed. 2d 177, 63 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 1077 (2004) (Rehnquist, J. concurring).
O.C.G.A. § 24-8-801(d)(2)(E); Shelton v. State, 279 Ga. 161, 163, 611 S.E.2d 11 (2005) (“statements made by co-conspirators are non-testimonial”).
See also Brooks v. State, 281 Ga. 14, 635 S.E.2d 723 (2006) (finding that admission of statements of co-conspirators were not testimonial and were sufficiently reliable).
